results.title: Vagabond = Sans toit ni loi
results.creator_credit: Agnes Varda, Oury Milshtein, Channel 4, Cine Tamaris and French Ministry of Culture
results.brief_description: Vagabond (Sans Toit Ni Loi) is considered by many to be one of Agnes Varda’s finest works and a classic of the nouvelle vague tradition of filmmaking. This is a coldly beautiful film that tells the story of Mona (Sandrine Bonnaire), a wanderer who moves from town to town living in her tent or with whoever will take her in. The film opens with Mona’s frozen body found lying in a ditch and proceeds to trace her story in a series of flashbacks to the point of her death. Bonnaire gives an impressive performance of the cold, and not completely likeable Mona, who remains distant to the people she meets and also the audience. Her distance intrigues on many levels. She talks of hoping to one day own a piece of land, and then later wishes to be the caretaker of a house. Given the opportunity for both, she moves on, seemingly unable to live anything but a nomadic existence. Rather than being a free spirit living a romanticised life free of society’s chains, Mona’s existence seems meaningless and emotionally void. Varda’s early career as a photographer is evident in her use of elegant framing and striking spacialization. The film won the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival and earned Sandrine Bonnaire a French Cesar award. Pauline Kael describes Varda thus: “A full-fledged visual filmmaker…Varda sustains an unsentimental yet subjective tone that is almost unique in the history of movies”. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Carry on sergeant
results.creator_credit: Gerald Thomas, Peter Rogers and Nat Cohen and Stuart Levy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Carry on”.
On the eve of retirement Sergeant Grimshaw (William Hartnell) hopes, with the arrival of his new and last National Service recruits, to retire with the honour of winning the Star Squad prize. His plans are tested when the recruits show themselves to be a motley crew of prankish misfits. The first in the Carry On series is a bright wartime comical farce. With only a few of the regular Carry On crew we see Kenneth Williams (as James Bailey) in one of his funniest performances. Cast also includes: Shirley Eaton, Eric Barker, Dora Bryan, Bill Owen, Charles Hawtrey, Kenneth Connor, Terence Longdon, Norman Rossington, Gerald Campion, Hattie Jacques, Cyril Chamberlain, Arnold Diamond and Gordon Tanner.

results.title: Carry on screaming
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Carry on”.
A virgin goes missing in the woods in this ‘Carry on’ spoof, leaving her boyfriend and two hopeless detectives in search of her. Their only clue is the remaining gruesome finger of a “homo-garganturoso” (an extinct hairy man) at the scene of the crime. They happen upon a spooky house, complete with expressionless butler, buxom vamp and an undead master of the house. When the lost finger is subjected to an electrical charge, another large hairy man is generated. Why does the mannequin resemble the missing girl and what is the vitrification process? The horror theme is made complete with the usual toilet humour and innuendo of the ‘Carry on’ crew. Cast includes Harry H. Corbett, Kenneth Williams and Joan Sims.

results.title: The Ruling class [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Medak, Jack Hawkins, Jules Buck and Keep Films
results.brief_description: Based on the stage play by Peter Barnes, this screen adaptation of “The Ruling class” (also written by Peter Barnes) remains true to the original farcical and darkly comic tale of British aristocracy. Combining the use of melodrama, musical and horror film genres, Peter Medak has created a totally bizarre visual feast of irony and parody of upper class England revolving around the rather unusual death of a British lord (Harry Andrews) who accidently hangs himself while in military uniform and a ballerina’s tutu. The Earl’s son, Jack Gurney (Peter O’Toole) becomes the 14th Earl of Gurney and finds himself named in the will as heir to the Gurney Estate. Only one problem - Jack is a paranoid schizophrenic who believes he is Jesus Christ. Jack’s disinherited relatives resolve to maintain their pride and their position as an upper class family and plot to have Jack committed to a mental institution and leave them as guardians to the Gurney Estate. However, Jack has to produce a family heir before any of this can take place. The lengths the family go to and the unexpected, hilarious and truly bizarre outcomes of their efforts, including Jack beginning to secretly think that he is Jack the Ripper and murdering one of the family members, add up to a most unusual and enjoyable cinematic experience consisting of narrative and vaudeville song-and-dance sequences, mixed in with a good measure of black comedy and contempt for the British class system. Cast also includes Arthur Lowe, Alastair Sim, Coral Browne, Michael Bryant, William Mervyn, Carolyn Seymour.

results.title: Play misty for me [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Robert Daley, Malpaso Company and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: In this contemporary thriller, Clint Eastwood plays the popular California disc jockey, Dave Garland. On his radio show he repeatedly receives a phone request for “Play Misty for Me”, from a feminine voice. Garland meets the owner of the mysterious voice, Evelyn Draper, at a night spot he frequents. Unsuspecting, he takes her home with him and there the terror begins. Stars Jessica Walter, Donna Mills and John Larch. Photographed by Bruce Surtees. Screenplay by Jo Heims and Dean Riesner. “Misty” composed and performed by Erroll Garner.

results.title: Cape fear (1991) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Amblin Entertainment, Cappa Films, Tribeca Productions and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Master filmmaker Scorcese tackled the re-make of the original 1962 classic with resounding success. Cape Fear is more than a journey towards terror and death. Fourteen years after being imprisoned, vicious psychopath Cady, played chillingly by Robert De Niro, emerges with a single-minded mission: to seek revenge on his attorney Sam Bowden, (Nick Nolte). His purpose, to upset the fragile equilibrium of Sam’s family life with his wife, (Jessica Lange), and teenage daughter, (Juliette Lewis), escalates until their very lives are threatened. Ultimately, Sam has to resort to unorthodox measures, but cannot escape the ultimate showdown in the murky, stormy waters of Cape Fear. Visually stunning images, and brilliant performances, plus cameo roles from original cast members (Gregory Peck, Robert Mitchum and Martin Balsam) highlight this roller-coaster ride through relentless psychological torment. Screenplay Wesley Strick, based on the screenplay by James R. Webb on the novel ‘The Executioners’ by John D. Macdonald. Bernard Herrmann’s original score has been adapted, arranged and conducted by Elmer Bernstein. Edited by Thelma Schoonmaker. Cinematography by Freddie Francis. Credits by Elaine and Saul Bass.

results.title: Cape Fear (1962) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: J Thompson, Sy Bartlett and Universal International Pictures
results.brief_description: Harrowing screen adaptation of John D. MacDonald’s novel ‘The Executioners’. Robert Mitchum is cast as the sadistic Max Cady, who has recently been released from prison and is determined to seek revenge on the lawyer who testified against him in a rape trial. Gregory Peck plays the targeted Savannah lawyer, Sam Bowden whose actions gradually spiral towards violence once Cady begins to harass his wife (Polly Bergen) and teenage daughter (Lori Martin). Unable to restrain Cady using legal methods, Bowden lures him to a remote location where he is free to confront him on equal terms. Cast includes: Martin Balsam, Jack Kruschen, Telly Savalas and Barrie Chase. Cinematography by Samuel Leavitt. Music by Bernard Herrmann. Screenplay by James R. Webb.

results.title: Quadrophenia
results.creator_credit: Franc Roddam, Bill Curbishley, Roy Baird, Polytel and The Who Films
results.brief_description: Jimmy (Phil Daniels) works in the post-office during the day in a job he hates. He lives for the weekends when he gets together with his mod friends, dresses up in sharp suits, pops amphetamine pills and dances to soul and power-pop in London clubs. The group of Mods decide to head down to Brighton for the weekend and while there, getting drunk and getting high on speed, they clash with a rival gang of working-class youth, the Rockers, whose musical tastes run to the legends of the fifties - Elvis, Bill Haley, Chuck Berry et. al. - and whose dress is blue-collar jeans and t-shirts. Set in 1965 and loosely based on The Who’s conceptual album of the same name, “Quadrophenia” is a kinetic film about youth culture, alienation and working class life. Featuring an explosive musical score by The Who, as well as great soul and rock music from the fifties and sixties, “Quadrophenia” is by turns both a perceptive and critical examination of leisure and work. Jimmy’s job confines him to a drudgery like that of his parents. It is a life that he wants to escape. He is free only through the exhilaration of music and drugs. With Sting, Toyah Willcox and Ray Winstone.

The group of Mods decide to head down to Brighton for the weekend and while there, getting drunk and getting high on speed, they clash with a rival gang of working-class youth, the Rockers, whose musical tastes run to the legends of the fifties - Elvis, Bill Haley, Chuck Berry et. al. - and whose dress is blue-collar jeans and t-shirts. Set in 1965 and loosely based on The Who’s conceptual album of the same name, “Quadrophenia” is a kinetic film about youth culture, alienation and working class life. Featuring an explosive musical score by The Who, as well as great soul and rock music from the fifties and sixties, “Quadrophenia” is by turns both a perceptive and critical examination of leisure and work. Jimmy’s job confines him to a drudgery like that of his parents. It is a life that he wants to escape. He is free only through the exhilaration of music and drugs. With Sting, Toyah Willcox and Ray Winstone.
description_for_label: Jimmy (Phil Daniels) works in the post-office during the day in a job he hates. He lives for the weekends when he gets together with his mod friends, dresses up in sharp suits, pops amphetamine pills and dances to soul and power-pop in London clubs. The group of Mods decide to head down to Brighton for the weekend and while there, getting drunk and getting high on speed, they clash with a rival gang of working-class youth, the Rockers, whose musical tastes run to the legends of the fifties - Elvis, Bill Haley, Chuck Berry et. al. - and whose dress is blue-collar jeans and t-shirts. Set in 1965 and loosely based on The Who’s conceptual album of the same name, “Quadrophenia” is a kinetic film about youth culture, alienation and working class life. Featuring an explosive musical score by The Who, as well as great soul and rock music from the fifties and sixties, “Quadrophenia” is by turns both a perceptive and critical examination of leisure and work. Jimmy’s job confines him to a drudgery like that of his parents. It is a life that he wants to escape. He is free only through the exhilaration of music and drugs. With Sting, Toyah Willcox and Ray Winstone.

results.title: The Filth and the fury
results.creator_credit: Julien Temple, Amanda Temple, Anita Camarata, Jersey Shore and Nitrate Films
results.brief_description: This honest film is suitable for both fans of the band and social historians. The documentary traces the dramatic rise and fall of the Sex Pistols in 70s London, using a collage of interesting footage from the time of chaos and rebellion. Throughout the film Shakespeare’s “Richard III” is irreverently referred to as being emblematic of the Sex Pistols being a band created during a time ripe for rebellion and individuality. The band members are interviewed in the shadows as if to keep their current identities hidden. These members give a personal account - as a voice over - throughout the documentary, bringing to life the rare footage of the punk movement.

results.title: An Officer and a gentleman
results.creator_credit: Taylor Hackford, Martin Elfand, Lorimar Film Entertainment and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Taylor Hackford (Against all odds, Proof of life) directed “An Officer and a gentleman”, starring Richard Gere and Debra Winger. It is the story of Zack Mayo (Gere) a man of uncertain future who is in conflict with his identity. A life of familial instability has left Zack unwilling to engage emotionally with others, especially women. Zack determines that he favours a career as a navy pilot, largely to prove to his alcoholic father that he is a son worthy of respect and capable of achievement. His steely demeanour suits military life but is in part broken down by his romance with a local factory girl Paula Pokrifi (Winger). Life in the armed forces is depicted as brutal and inhumane as the recruits make their way through a gruelling 13-week course. Foley, (Louis Gossett, Jnr) the irascible Major in charge of the recruits, rides Mayo particularly hard as he recognises in him Officer material. Mayo is torn between his cold conduct that shelters him from feeling anything and his burgeoning love for Paula. “An Officer and a gentleman” won Oscars for Gosset (Best Supporting Actor) and Best Song for “Up where we belong”.
